title: 111_hr2392
content: The Act is titled the "Government Information Transparency Act" and includes data standard requirements. The "Government Information Transparency Act" mandates the adoption of single data standards for business and financial information by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. These standards must be common across all agencies, open source, non-proprietary, and consistent with US accounting principles. The Government Information Transparency Act requires the adoption of single data standards for business and financial information by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. These standards must align with US accounting principles, industry best practices, and Federal regulatory requirements to enhance transparency, consistency, and usability of information. The standards should also be continually upgradable to keep pace with evolving technologies and content. The Government Information Transparency Act mandates the adoption of a single data standard for private sector business and financial information to improve transparency and consistency. The OMB will issue guidance to agencies on implementing a single data standard for private sector information reporting. Agencies must require the use of this standard for business and financial data from private companies, starting within one year of the Act's enactment. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will develop a single data standard for Federal financial information within one year of the Act's enactment. Guidance on its use will be issued to agencies within 18 months. Agencies must ensure public access to information collected using the standard. Within one year of the Act's enactment, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit a report on the implementation status to relevant committees. Definitions are provided in the Act. The term "agency" in the Act refers to various government entities within the executive branch, excluding specific organizations like the Government Accountability Office and the Federal Election Commission. It also excludes certain government entities at the local level and government-owned contractor-operated facilities involved in national defense activities. The terms "Executive department", "military department", "Government corporation", "Government controlled corporation", and "independent establishment" are defined in chapter 1 of title 5, United States Code. The term "independent regulatory agency" is defined in section 3502(5) of title 44, United States Code.
